qas.question: As what was Elizabeth portrayed in the 1950s?
What was the time after WWII heralded as?
Of what did Lord Altrincham say Elizabeth's speeches resembled?
What investiture featuring Prince Charles was televised in the late 1960s?
In the 1960s, what did Elizabeth begin wearing to events ?
In what year did Lord Altrincham receive his lordship?
What does Prince Charles tend to wear out in public?
Who directed the television documentary Royal Family in the late 1960s?
who first called it a "new Elizabethan age"?

plausible_answers.text: speeches sounded like those of a "priggish schoolgirl"

qas.question: What has Prince Charles been accused of by one of his critics?

context: In the 1950s, as a young woman at the start of her reign, Elizabeth was depicted as a glamorous <a0_0>"fairytale Queen"<a0_0/>. After the trauma of the Second World War, it was a time of hope, a period of progress and achievement heralding a <a1_0>"new Elizabethan age"<a1_0/>. <b7_0><b8_0>Lord Altrincham<b8_0/><b7_0/>'s accusation in <b5_0>1957<b5_0/> that her <b9_0>speeches sounded like those of a <a2_0>"priggish schoolgirl"<b9_0/><a2_0/> was an extremely rare criticism. In the late 1960s, attempts to portray a more modern image of the monarchy were made in the television documentary Royal Family and by televising Prince Charles's investiture as <a3_0>Prince of Wales<a3_0/>. In public, she took to wearing mostly <a4_0><b6_0>solid-colour overcoats<b6_0/><a4_0/> and decorative hats, which allow her to be seen easily in a crowd.
